column3: is believed to have been named in 1859 for the Engle family. The community had been called the "English Neighborhood"

column2: Englewood switched from a Mayor-Council form of government to a modified Council-Manager plan of government in accordance with a Special Charter granted by the New Jersey Legislature. The city is one of 11 municipalities (of the 565) statewide that use a special charter granted by the Legislature. The governing body is comprised of the Mayor and the City Council. Under this charter
column3: the mayor has powers to appoint and veto
column4: while the council functions as a legislative body
column5: with some power to appoint and confirm appointments. The city is divided into four wards which are approximately equal in population. The City Council is comprised of five members
column6: each elected for a three-year term. Four are elected from the individual wards in which they live and the other is elected by a citywide vote as an at-large member. Administrative functions are responsibilities of the City Manager. The six seats in the governing body are elected in a three-year cycle as part of the November general election
column7: with wards two and four both up together
column8: followed a year later by wards one and three
column9: and then the at-large council and mayoral seats. Each ward votes in two of the three years in the cycle
column11: in the other year for the two positions voted at-large and one year with no election.The mayor appoints members to the Planning Board
column15: the Board of Adjustment. The mayor serves on the Planning Board. The mayor attends and may speak at council meetings
column16: but only votes to break a tie for passage of an ordinance or resolution. The mayor has veto power over ordinances
column17: but can be overridden with votes from four council members. The City Council is the legislative branch of government
column22: and hiring the City Manager. The City Council meets generally four times per month (except during summer months).

column1: Several NJ Transit bus lines serve Englewood. The 166 provides local and express service to and from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Midtown Manhattan; the 171
column3: 178 and 186 provide service to / from the George Washington Bridge Bus Station in uptown Manhattan; and the 756 and 780 offer local service. Rockland Coaches provides scheduled service to / from the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Routes 21T

column8: and 20T. Saddle River Tours / Ameribus provides rush hour service on weekdays to / from the George Washington Bridge Bus Station on the 11C and 20/84 routes.Erie Railroad's suburban Northern Branch (NRRNJ) started passenger service in Englewood in 1859
column9: at various stations including the still extant building at Depot Square. It  originated/terminated at Pavonia Terminal on the Hudson River in Jersey City and was ended in September 1966 (by which time trains had been redirected to Hoboken Terminal).The Northern Branch Corridor Project is a proposed NJ Transit (NJT) project to extend the Hudson–Bergen Light Rail along the line providing service to newly built stations along the route. The line would stop at Englewood Route 4 and Englewood Town Center and terminate at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center. A station stop at Depot Square is the city's much-preferred alternative to NJT's proposed new Englewood Town Center Station to the south. Englewood Mayor Frank Huttle III has worked together with Jersey City Mayor Steven Fulop to advocate on behalf of the project and obtain the needed state and federal funding needed to proceed with the plan
column10: with Huttle emphasizing the economic benefits from the project and that the city wanted to host the terminus
column11: which would include a parking garage near Englewood Hospital and additional parking near Palisade Avenue in the commercial center of the city.
